metadata.case_name: Balwant Singh & Anr. v. Income-tax Officer

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 was the Income-tax Officer for Additional B-VIII District, New Delhi between June 16, 1962, and May 4, 1964.
Appellants carried on business in partnership as M/s. Balwant Singh Santok Singh within the said Additional B-VIII Income-tax District.
For assessment year 1960-61 (accounting year 1959-60), the firm was registered under section 26A of the Income-tax Act, 1922.

During assessment proceedings for assessment year 1961-62 (accounting year 1960-61), respondent No. 1 noticed that the firm had not applied for renewal of registration and was liable to be assessed as an unregistered firm.
Appellant No. 1 (Balwant Singh) represented to respondent No. 1 that the firm had filed an application for renewal for assessment year 1961-62 within the prescribed period.
Respondent No. 1 adjourned the case to May 27, 1963, and called upon appellant No. 1 to produce evidence of the application.
On May 27, 1963, appellant No. 1 produced a certificate of posting dated June 21, 1961, and a duplicate application dated June 15, 1961, purporting to prove posting of the original application.
Respondent No. 1 noticed that the form of the certificate dated June 21, 1961, was printed in 1962, arousing suspicion about its genuineness.
Respondent No. 1 recorded statement on oath of appellant No. 1, who asserted the certificate and posting were genuine.

Respondent No. 1 rejected the claim for renewal, assessed the firm as unregistered, held that appellants fabricated the documents and used them knowing them to be false, and that appellant No. 1 gave false evidence on oath.
In the assessment order dated May 27, 1963, there was a note at the foot that appellants should be prosecuted, but no formal order to prosecute was passed in the assessment order itself.

On October 26, 1964, after respondent No. 1 had ceased to be the Income-tax Officer of the Additional B-VIII District, he lodged a complaint before the Magistrate alleging offences under sections 193 and 196 of the Penal Code for fabricating false evidence and using forged documents in proceedings under section 26A.
Appellants filed application under section 561A CrPC before High Court of Punjab (Circuit Bench, New Delhi) to quash the complaint; application rejected.
Appellants obtained special leave from Supreme Court and filed appeal.

legal_issues.text: Whether Income-tax Officer acting under section 26A of Income-tax Act, 1922 is a court and must follow procedure in sections 476 or 479A CrPC before filing complaint for offences under sections 193 and 196 IPC.
Whether respondent No. 1, having ceased to hold charge of the post on date of filing complaint (October 26, 1964), filed complaint without jurisdiction.

petitioner_arguments.text: Income-tax Officer while acting under section 26A is a court, so must follow sections 476 and 479A CrPC before filing complaint for offences under sections 193 and 196 IPC.
Respondent No. 1 ceased to hold charge of Income-tax Officer for Additional B-VIII District on date of complaint, so complaint filed without jurisdiction.

court_reasoning.text: Proceedings under section 26A before Income-tax Officer are judicial proceedings within meaning of sections 193, 196 IPC and treated as proceedings in a court for section 195(1)(b) CrPC due to section 37 IT Act 1922, but Income-tax Officer is not a civil, revenue or criminal court.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Sections 476 and 479A apply only to civil, revenue or criminal courts; Income-tax Officer not such a court, so no need to follow those procedures.

court_reasoning.text: Second contention is a question of evidence; possible that Commissioner allotted/continued cases post-transfer; to be raised before Magistrate.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Decline to go into question at this stage.

holdings.text: Proceedings before Income-tax Officer under section 26A are judicial proceedings in a court for purposes of section 195(1)(b) CrPC, but officer not a revenue court, so sections 476/479A not applicable.
Issue of jurisdiction post-cessation of post is question of evidence for trial court.

precedents_cited.relevance: Bombay HC view that ITO/Sales TO is revenue court; not approved by SC.
Bombay HC view that Sales Tax Officer is revenue court; not approved.

precedents_cited.case_name: Jagannath Prasad v. State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Sales Tax Officer not a court within section 195(1)(b) CrPC.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ujjam Bai v. State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Sales Tax Officer not a court.

precedents_cited.case_name: Lalji Haridas v. State of Maharashtra
precedents_cited.relevance: Proceedings before ITO judicial for IPC 193/196/228; treated as in court for CrPC 195(1)(b), but ITO not revenue court.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Registration/renewal proceedings; deem proceedings judicial for IPC 193/196.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code, 1860
statutes_cited.relevance: Punishment for false evidence, fabricating false evidence.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898
statutes_cited.relevance: Complaint requirement for offences in judicial proceedings; procedure for prosecution.

outcome.summary: Court rejected both contentions of appellants; first fails as sections 476/479A inapplicable; second is question of evidence for Magistrate. Appeal dismissed implicitly by upholding High Court order refusing to quash complaint.

key_quotes.text: "Though, therefore, proceedings before the Income-tax Officer are judicial proceedings in a court and section 195(1)(b) applies, neither section 476 nor section 479A of the Code would be applicable."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on inapplicability of procedural sections.

key_quotes.text: "The question being one of evidence the appellant can raise it before the Magistrate trying the complaint."
key_quotes.speaker: court
